question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
The solution for a differential equation of the form \(\frac{\mathrm{d}x }{\mathrm{d} t} = Ax(t)\) and A is 2 by 2 and diagonalizable has the form

\(x(t) = c_1v_1e^{\lambda_1 t} + c_2v_2e^{\lambda_2 t}\) where \(\lambda\) are the eigenvalues of A and \(v\) are their respective eigenvectors.

\(c_1, c_2\) can be obtained by plugging in the initial condition \(x(0) = \begin{bmatrix} 4\\1 \end{bmatrix}\)

Solving \(\begin{bmatrix} 4\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = c_1\begin{bmatrix} 1\\2 \end{bmatrix} + c_2\begin{bmatrix} 0\\1 \end{bmatrix}\) should give you \(c_1 = 4, c_2 = -7\)

therefore the solution is \(x(t) = 4e^{t}\begin{bmatrix} 1\\2 \end{bmatrix} - 7e^{0.5t}\begin{bmatrix} 0\\1 \end{bmatrix}\)
statement_html:
Consider the diagonalizable matrix \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \\ 1 & 0.5 \end{bmatrix}= \begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \\ 0&0.5 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \\ 2& 1 \end{bmatrix}^{-1}\)

(b) Find the solution \(x(t) =\begin{bmatrix} x_1(t)\\ x_2(t) \end{bmatrix}\) of the differential equation \(\displaystyle \frac{dx(t)}{dt} = Ax(t)\) satisfying the initial condition \(x_0 = \begin{bmatrix} 4\\1 \end{bmatrix}\).
